items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message: River and lake levels remain high on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water due to recent rainfall. Today, Friday 4/11/2022, is forecast to be dry, and the lake level at the Lodore gauge is receding. However the lake will remain high for at least the next few days, with further rain forecast over the coming weekend. Flooding is affecting locations near these rivers and the lake, with low lying land most affected, particularly around the Upper Derwent from Seathwaite to Derwent Water. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 05/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Wey
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high on the Upper Wey at Godalming as a result of persistent heavy rainfall last night. Therefore, flooding of low-lying roads, footpaths and farmland is still expected. 
Light showers are expected over the coming days, but we expect levels on the river to drop slowly today.
We will continue to monitor the situation and will update this message later today, 04/11/22 or if the situation changes.

items.description: River Pinn and Woodridings Stream
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  

River levels have now fallen following heavy rainfall on Wednesday 2nd and Thursday 3rd November. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. There is no more rainfall forecast over the next 24 hours. We recommend that you avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses as there may still be standing water in some locations. 

Our incident response staff are constantly monitoring the situation and are ready to respond if required. We recommend that you remain aware of the forecast for the next 5 days.

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high on the Chertsey Bourne as a result of persistent heavy rainfall over the last few nights. Therefore, flooding of low-lying roads and farmland is expected this evening 04/11/22, especially in the Free Prae Road area. Levels should fall today and forecast to follow below the threshold for alert.
Today will be dry with light rain forecast tomorrow.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated later today 04/11/22, or if the situation changes.

items.message: Water levels have risen at the Sherborne Lake river gauge as a result of the recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, there remains a low risk of flooding to low-lying land and roads. Locations most vulnerable to flooding are the Sparkford to Weston Bampfylde road and Deep Ford Lane, Chetnole. Further rainfall is forecast early morning, Saturday, 5/11/2022 so we expect river levels to remain high. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers which may be flooded; refer to local authority website for local road closures. This message will be updated by 12:00 on Saturday, 5/11/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Uck
items.message: River levels in Buxted and Uckfield are high, but steadily falling, following Friday morning's rain. River levels in Isfield are high and rising but should begin to fall around 11:00, Friday 04/11/2022. Minor flooding will continue to affect riverside properties at Isfield Mill and Isfield Bridge and water will remain in fields, gardens and on rural roads along the whole River Uck. A dry day is forecast for Friday, which should allow the river to return to a more normal level by Friday evening. Some rain is forecast for both Saturday and Sunday. At the moment less than 10mm is expected Saturday, but 25mm of rain forecast for Sunday, which could cause some further flooding. Please remain prepared for the possibility of flooding on Sunday 06/11/2022. Please keep flood protection products installed, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 22:00 on 04/11/2022.

items.message:
River levels in the Hendon, Wembley, Harrow, Wealdstone, Edgware and Stanmore areas have now fallen following heavy rainfall in the early hours of this morning, Thursday 3rd November 2022. 

We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Further light rainfall is forecast this evening, and into tomorrow morning, Friday 4th November but we do not expect any further flooding. 

We recommend that you avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses as there may still be standing water in some locations. 

Our incident response staff are monitoring the situation and clearing trash screens where necessary. We recommend that you remain aware of the forecast for the next 5 days. There is currently more heavy rain forecast on Sunday 6th November.

items.description: Buxted
items.message: River levels in Buxted are high, but steadily falling, following Friday morning's rain. A dry day is forecast for Friday, which should allow the river to return to a more normal level by Friday evening. Some rain is forecast for both Saturday and Sunday. At the moment less than 10mm is expected Saturday, but 25mm of rain forecast for Sunday, which could cause some further flooding. Please remain prepared for the possibility of flooding on Sunday 06/11/2022. Riverside properties in Buxted are encouraged to keep their flood protection products close by, or installed, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast, and we will re-issue this Flood Warning if we believe properties are expected to flood.

items.description: River Teise area from Lamberhurst to Goudhurst
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  River levels have now fallen below the level expected to cause flooding from recent rainfall.  No further rainfall is forecast for today, Friday 4 November 2022.  

Our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from rivers.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

items.description: River Adur East Branch
items.message: The River Adur is high and currently slowly rising, following 20mm of rain Thursday night, in addition to the 45mm of rain on Thursday morning. Flooding will continue to affect the A281 at Mock Bridge, near Shermanbury until Saturday 05/11/22. As well as there being extensive water in fields, flooding will also affect properties near Mock Bridge and their gardens. A dry day is forecast for Friday 04/11/22. River levels should begin to fall around midday Friday, but are unlikely to return to a more normal level until Saturday afternoon. Some rain is forecast for both Saturday and Sunday. At the moment less than 10mm is expected Saturday. On Sunday, 25mm of rain is forecast, which could cause some further flooding. Please remain prepared for the possibility of flooding on Sunday 06/11/2022. Some roads, including the A281 at Mock Bridge, may become impassable. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 22:00 on 04/11/2022.

items.description: Eastern Yar
items.message: The water level in the Eastern Yar is just peaking at Alverstone. At Sandown, it continues to rise. Last night, a further 16mm of rain was recorded at Knighton. Road, cycle path and footpath flooding is expected. At Alverstone, the river will be close to the top of the river bank, and out of bank flooding is expected at Langbridge. At Sandown, Golf Links Road and Moreton Common Road will be flooded. Ditches around Fort Holiday Park will struggle to drain while the river is high. Property flooding is not currently expected. Rain has now cleared the area, and Friday is forecast to be dry. At Alverstone, the river level will begin falling later this morning (04/11/22). At Sandown, the river will not peak until this evening (04/11/22). Further showers are forecast this weekend. If these affect the area, river levels will be high throughout this period. We are operating the sluice at Bembridge to reduce water levels across Brading marshes. Please ensure products used to protect gardens and property are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 16:00 on Friday 04/11/22.

items.description: River Blackwater and The Cove Brook
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high on the River Blackwater as a result of persistent heavy rainfall over the last few nights. Therefore, flooding of low-lying roads, footpaths and farmland is expected this evening today, especially in the Swallowfield area. 
Today will be dry, with a more showers tomorrow morning, therefore levels should start to fall.
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and avoid contact with flood water. 
This message will be updated later today, 04/11/22, or if the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Ouse
items.message: The River Ouse remains high following Thursday's heavy rain. In the early hours of Friday another 15mm of rain was recorded, and the upper Ouse near Ardingly is rising again. Flood impacts will continue to affect all communities through Friday, including near Ardingly and Lindfield Bridge on the B2028 near Lindfield, rural roads and gardens near Freshfield Mill Farm on Sloop Lane, Bridge Cottage at Sheffield Park, Fletching Mill Bridge, Sharpsbridge, and areas of Barcombe Mills, with Anchor Lane and Barcombe Mills Road affected by flood water. River levels should fall Friday afternoon and the river return to a more normal level by Saturday 05/11/2022. However, 25mm of rain forecast for Sunday, could cause some further flooding. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including Barcombe Mills Road. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Barcombe, if you have them. We are operating our structures in Barcombe to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 21:00 04/11/2022.

items.description: The upper Stour and surrounding tributaries
items.message: Levels are now well below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no significant rainfall overnight into tomorrow, but further rain is expected at the weekend. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: Cuckmere River
items.message: The Cuckmere River in Alfriston is still very high, but now slowly falling. Flooding will continue to affect The Old Clergy House, Deans Place Hotel, North Street, Willows Car Park and River Lane. The Cuckmere and Bull Rivers through Hellingly are still higher than normal, but significantly lower than Thursday's peak. A dry day is forecast for Friday, but minor flood impacts will continue to affect gardens of properties on Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road, Hellingly until Saturday. In Alfriston river levels could remain above average until next week. Some rain is forecast for both Saturday and Sunday. At the moment less than 10mm is expected Saturday, but 25mm of rain forecast for Sunday, which could cause some further flooding. Please remain prepared for the possibility of further flooding on Sunday 06/11/2022. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including North Street, Alfriston and keep flood protection products installed, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 22:00 on 04/11/2022.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

River levels are now falling, having peaked in Lamberhurst early afternoon on Thursday 3 November 2022 but still pose a flood risk to roads, gardens and fields.  

We continue to monitor the situation. Our incident response staff are ensuring that rivers are flowing freely and that any structures are working correctly.

items.description: Hellingly and Horsebridge
items.message: The Cuckmere and Bull Rivers through Hellingly are still higher than normal, but significantly lower than Thursday's peak. In the early hours of Friday another 15mm of rain was recorded, which will delay the river's return to normal. Minor flood impacts will continue to affect gardens of properties on Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road, Hellingly through Friday. Nearby fields and rural roads will be affected too. A Flood Alert remains in force to cater for this flood risk. A dry day Friday should see the river return to a more normal level by Saturday 05/11/2022. However, 25mm of rain forecast for Sunday, could cause some further flooding. Please remain prepared for the possibility of further flooding on Sunday 06/11/2022. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road, Hellingly. items.description: Barcombe Mills
items.message: The River Ouse remains very high through Barcombe, following Thursday's heavy rain. River levels are currently falling, but flood impacts will continue to affect a small number of properties in Barcombe Mills and at the Anchor Inn, with Barcombe Mills Road and Anchor Lane likely to be impassable. Flood water will continue to be extensive through fields. In the early hours of Friday another 15mm of rain was recorded, and the upper Ouse near Ardingly is rising again. This will likely slow the fall in water level at Barcombe, possibly causing a slight rise Friday afternoon. A dry day Friday should see the river return to a more normal level by Saturday 05/11/2022. However, 25mm of rain forecast for Sunday, could cause some further flooding. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including Barcombe Mills Road. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Barcombe, if you have them. We are operating our structures in Barcombe to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 21:00 04/11/2022.

items.message: The Cuckmere River in Alfriston is still very high, but now slowly falling. A dry day is forecast for Friday, which should allow river levels to continue to fall. However, flood impacts and high river levels in Alfriston could remain until next week. Some rain is forecast for both Saturday and Sunday. At the moment less than 10mm is expected Saturday, but 25mm of rain forecast for Sunday, which could cause some further flooding. Please remain prepared for the possibility of further flooding on Sunday 06/11/2022. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including North Street, Alfriston and keep flood protection products installed, if you have them. River levels are rising steadily on the Middle Dorset Stour due to rainfall.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Middle Dorset Stour.
Flooding is possible at tributaries between Sturminster Newton and Wimborne between 07:30 AM and 03:00 PM on 04/11/2022.
No further rainfall is forecast.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 02:30 PM on 04/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Eden and Eden Brook
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels have risen as a result of heavy rainfall.  Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected from 8am today, Friday 4 November 2022 through the morning as a result of recent rainfall overnight.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads close to the rivers, particularly on and around Water Lane and Haxted Road. No further rainfall is expected today. 

We are continuing to monitor the situation and our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from the rivers. Please avoid using footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  

This message will be updated by 6pm, or as the situation changes.
